Hey Tim,
Love your channel and your work.
I have a question about the SLS and I guess back to the shuttle program.
Why do they not use the main tank on the SLS as the building block for a space station?
I mean they take the dam thing all the way to space then throw it away!!
Its not like it is a new concept, they used an upper stage of a Saturn rocket for Skylab so why not use the main tank on the SLS. Imagine how many of them would be there now if they used the space shuttles tank. 135!!! Now that space station would have been HUGE!!
I hate to see good resources wasted.
Anyway thanks for doing what you do and keep it up

1:26:30 Funny how we get back to the original Atlas concept of a stainless steel balloon ;-) Those Atlases went right into orbit (minus a couple of nozzles or motors)... starting in 1958. Closest thing to an SSTO... perhaps the Starship will be the first complete SSTO (but without a payload).

Tim: Ask  Elon if they have considered using balanced "aerodynamic flaps" to reduce power required. i.e., if the pivot point is 1/3rd away from the mounting hinge the forces are split between the inner and outer area. Used on yachts and aircraft. Conceptually, if pivot point is 50% then forces are balanced so tiny energy needed - but it does not work out like that due to oscillation and vibration factors !!! 30% is about the maximum in practice' But you have the concept......... I am a stress engineer and airline pilot so qualified to comment.
